titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the 1888 and 1892 Republican campaign songbooks and pamphlet 1977.018
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-08-25 13:40:40 +0000.

did.unittitle: 1888 and 1892 Republican campaign songbooks and pamphlet
did.abstract: This collection consists of three songbooks issued by various Republican organizations, including the National Republican League of the United States, for the 1888 and 1892 Presidential campaigns.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); 1888 and 1892 Republican campaign songbooks and pamphlet, 1977.018, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. Formally accessioned in 1977.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of three songbooks issued by various Republican organizations, including the National Republican League of the United States, for the 1888 and 1892 Presidential campaigns. The songbooks concern a variety of political and social issues, including slavery. An 1888 pamphlet issued by the Brooklyn Young Republican Club containing a historical sketch comparing the protection of domestic industries and free trade is also included.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The 1888 United States Presidential election was between Democratic incumbent Grover Cleveland and Republican nominee Benjamin Harrison, and resulted in a victory for Harrison. Cleveland won the Presidency back from Harrison in 1892, and in so doing became the only United States President ever to serve two non-consecutive terms.
